title: Clifton DeBerry
text:
Clifton DeBerry (September 18, 1923 – March 24, 2006) was an American <a href="communist">communist</a> and two-time candidate for <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">President of the United States</a> of the <a href="Socialist%20Workers%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Socialist Workers Party</a>. He was the first black American in the 20th century to be chosen by a political party as its nominee for president.
Biography.
Early years.
Clifton DeBerry was born in September 1923 in <a href="Holly%20Springs%2C%20Mississippi">Holly Springs, Mississippi</a>. He worked as a house painter and was a <a href="trade%20union">trade union</a>ist.
In the 1940s, DeBerry left his native South and moved to <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>, where he worked in a factory owned by <a href="International%20Harvester">International Harvester</a>. He became active in the Farm Equipment Workers Union and joined the <a href="Communist%20Party%20USA">Communist Party</a>. DeBerry grew critical of the official Communist movement, and in 1953 he joined the <a href="Socialist%20Workers%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Socialist Workers Party</a>, a <a href="Trotskyist">Trotskyist</a> organization.
During his Chicago years in the late 1950s, DeBerry found it hard to keep a job. "I would get a job and it would last only 3 days. I would go from one job to another. The <a href="FBI">FBI</a> would visit my boss and I would be fired." DeBerry gave up on the city and moved to <a href="New%20York%20City">New York</a> in 1960.
Political career.
DeBerry's career as a political activist began in earnest in the 1950s. In 1955 he helped organize a mass protest in Chicago to protest the <a href="lynching">lynching</a> of <a href="Emmett%20Till">Emmett Till</a> back home in his native Mississippi. DeBerry spoke out in defense of the <a href="Cuban%20Revolution">Cuban Revolution</a>, in support of African liberation struggles, and demanded withdrawal of U.S. troops from <a href="Vietnam%20War">Vietnam</a>.
DeBerry marched for <a href="civil%20rights">civil rights</a> in <a href="Selma%2C%20Alabama">Selma, Alabama</a> and <a href="Memphis%2C%20Tennessee">Memphis, Tennessee</a> and was a supporter of <a href="Malcolm%20X">Malcolm X</a> in the 1960s. He was a delegate to the founding conventions of the <a href="Negro%20Labor%20Congress">Negro Labor Congress</a> and the <a href="Negro%20American%20Labor%20Council">Negro American Labor Council</a>.
In November 1963, DeBerry ran for councilman in the <a href="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a> borough of New York City. He received 3,514 votes in the race.
DeBerry was the Socialist Workers Party's candidate in the <a href="1964%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">1964 election</a>. He was the party's first <a href="African%20American">African American</a> candidate as well as the first African American candidate for president of any existing party (he was preceded in 1960 by marginal candidate <a href="Clennon%20King">Clennon King</a>). DeBerry's running mate was <a href="Ed%20Shaw%20%28activist%29">Ed Shaw</a>, a printer from <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>.
In the 1965 city election, DeBerry was the SWP's candidate for <a href="Mayor%20of%20New%20York">Mayor of New York</a>.
In <a href="1970%20New%20York%20state%20election">1970</a>, he ran for <a href="Governor%20of%20New%20York">Governor of New York</a> and polled 5,766 votes.
DeBerry ran again in the <a href="1980%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">1980 United States presidential election</a> as one of three candidates the party had that year, the others being <a href="Andrew%20Pulley">Andrew Pulley</a> and <a href="Richard%20Congress">Richard Congress</a>. <a href="Matilde%20Zimmermann">Matilde Zimmermann</a> was the <a href="United%20States%20Vice%20President">vice presidential</a> candidate on all three tickets.
Death and legacy.
Clifton DeBerry died of heart failure on March 24, 2006 in a hospital near his home of <a href="Union%20City%2C%20California">Union City, California</a>. He was 82 years old. A memorial meeting was held in his honor by the Socialist Workers Party in New York City on April 29, 2006.
